Hi all, Recently, the mods have been (privately) asked about "what's the deal with the no-politics rule?", e.g. where is the line, and what's considered OK or not OK. Also, for some odd reason politics seem to be coming up a lot these days, can't imagine why. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif ":)") So it's worth a few notes on the subject: In general, this forum tries to be a "hands-off" place, for the most part: i.e. as much as possible, just let people say what they want to say. The forum guidelines were written with that in mind, and the moderators generally aim for a policy of "the less moderation, the better." So the rules that we *do* have are generally there for very pragmatic reasons: they're there because bitter experience has shown that Bad Things happen if they're not. So, politics is one of those areas that has proven to be untouchable. It's been shown consistently over the years that it's simply not possible to have any significant mention of politics without it quickly blowing up into a massive flame-war where nobody wins, because people feel so strongly about these things. And since politics have nothing to do with KSP itself, we can draw the line there with a clean conscience that we're not impeding the free discussion of KSP, which is what this forum is about. If people really want to talk politics, there are plenty of other forums where they can do it. So, that raises the interesting question: just what **is** considered "politics", then? Well, in this context, we pretty much have to treat it like art: hard to define, but "we know it when we see it." What constitutes "politics" is a very fuzzy boundary that's hard to sharply define (for one thing, a lot can depend on context.) So that's why the rule is deliberately left fairly vague: to give the moderators reasonable latitude for judgment. Basically, **it's politics if the mods think it's politics**. Yes, that is, unfortunately, arbitrary. Unavoidably so. Because that's unavoidably arbitrary, we try to take care against the vagaries of individual judgment. In particular, we try to avoid making such decisions individually: if a moderator notices something that seems excessively political, they'll consult with other moderators before taking any action. Well, okay, I hear you ask, in that case, how do moderators "judge" this, typically? Basically, it boils down to: "does it have a high potential to erupt in a flame war?" Which rules out just about anything political, given how high passions generally run about these things. Please understand: when the moderators enforce these rules, it's not because of any opinions on politics, or any concern about the issues in question-- simply that they lead to toxic exchanges in the forums that don't benefit anyone. Some concrete examples of stuff that fits that description: - Making pretty much any reference at all-- even in jest-- about specific candidates in current elections, in any country - Making generalizations about particular countries - Discussing the rightness or wrongness of just about any governmental action-- laws, budgets, etc. **Those are just a few examples and not intended to be an exhaustive list.** And even those examples are a bit vague: everything depends on context, and the nature of the individual post. The "it depends" dictum also bears not just on what the content is, but what the moderator response is after tidying up. For example: An innocent user, with a clean record, who happens to make a casual politics-related joke because they didn't realize it was out of bounds, and clearly meant no harm by it? Probably just a gentle reminder "please don't do politics, even in jest." An angry political rant dropped like a bomb into an otherwise non-political thread? Probably something a bit harsher, especially if the user has been warned for it before. It all depends. So that's the deal from the moderators' perspective. How does this apply to you? Here's what the mods would like to request of all the users: - Please, just don't do politics here, okay? There are other places for that. - If you see someone else doing politics, please **don't respond**. - If someone seems to be posting stuff that's over the line, **don't call them on it** (that's "backseat moderating", it's against forum rule 3.2). Instead, just **report the post**, along with an explanatory note, and let the moderators take care of anything that may need taking care of. It's what we're *for*. - I know that all of the above sounds vague and hand-wavy. Can't be helped, I'm sorry. If you have more specific questions about specific instances, please feel free to privately message any of the moderator staff and we'll be happy to weigh in (with the understanding that, due to privacy concerns, we can never discuss moderator action against a user with anyone other than that user). **TL;DR:** Politics are against the rules, but there are some light edge cases where you might get away with it. Don't try.
